Functional evaluation of plant defence signalling against fusarium ear blight disease in arabidopsis

Fusarium ear blight is an important fungal disease of cereals which is difficult to control. We have previously demonstrated (Urban et al ., 2002, The Plant Journal 32 , 961-973) that Fusarium graminearum and Fusarium culmorum can infect the floral tissues of arabidopsis to cause disease symptoms on flowers, siliques and upper stem tissue. DON mycotoxin production accompanies these floral infections.
Arabidopsis ecotype La-er inoculated with F. culmorum conidia, 7 days post-inoculation

The arabidopsis-fusarium model seems likely to provide a tractable pathosystem for elucidating fundamental aspects of the plant-pathogen interaction with direct relevance to the significant problems resulting from these infections in cereal crops.
The two main aims of our research are to develop a comprehensive understanding of
• the plant defence signalling networks operating in floral tissue to confer resistance against the fungal pathogens F. graminearum and F. culmorum, and
• the plant signals and pathways that induce and regulate in planta trichothecene mycotoxin production.
Chemical structure of DON mycotoxin (drawn by Samuel Dufour, RRes)

1. Screening the repertoire of known arabidopsis defence signalling mutants for altered susceptibility. (List of arabidopsis mutants and transgenes known to compromise or enhance plant defence without causing spontaneous cell death/lesion formation (Hammond-Kosack and Parker, 2003 Current Opinions in Biotechnology 14 , 177-193).
Arabidopsis plants grown in a controlled growth room
To facilitate this screen transgenic fusarium strains constitutively expressing either the GFP (green flurorescent protein) or GUS (ß
column2: - glucuronidase) reporter gene will be used to identify the spatial and temporal distribution of fungal biomass.

column1: F. culmorum constitutively expressing GFP grown on a microscope slide

Conidia from a F. culmorum strain constitutively expressing GFP, inoculated onto the cut upper stem of a primary bolt of Arabidopsis ecotype Ler-O. Photomicrograph of the upper cut stem taken 5 days post-inoculation revealing extensive mycelial growth.
2. Determination of plant signals regulating trichothecene mycotoxin production using the F. graminearum transgenic strain of PH-1 harbouring a TRI5 promoter:GFP:GUS reporter construct.

3. Forward genetics selections and screens of EMS mutagenised seed to identify arabidopsis mutants compromised or enhanced in plant defence against fusarium floral disease, tolerant to DON mycotoxin or DON non-inducers.
4. Completion of the secondary screens / selections to confirm arabidopsis mutants and identification of the chromosomal location of the variant genes.

Arabidopsis floral tissue 5 days after spray inoculation with F. graminearum conidia. The white square indicates the stem tissue region examined by trypan blue-lactophenol staining (right panel). Intercellular and intracellular hyphal growth is evident in the parenchyma tissue.
This project is funded by a BBSRC responsive mode grant (PMS committee).
